item.title: ER DIAGRAM
item.description:
• Entities represented by rectangles.
  • Attributes represented by circles/ellipses.
  • Key attributes are underlined.
  • Relationships represented by diamonds
  • Cardinality represented by arrows
  • Lines link attributes to entity sets and entity sets to relationship sets.

PARTICIPATION CONSTRAINT

A participation constraint defines how every member of entity set participates in the relationship.

Total participation:

Every member of entity set must participate in the relationship

Represented by bold line from entity rectangle to relationship diamond

item.title: NORMAL FORMS
item.description:
ARMSTRONG’S AXIOMS

  • Reflexivity rule: X → a subset of X
  • Augmentation rule: X → Y, then XZ → YZ
  • Transitivity rule: X → Y and Y → Z then X→Z
  • Union rule: X→Y and X→Z, then X→YZ (X, Y, Z are sets of attributes)
  • Decomposition rule: X → YZ, then X → Y and X → Z
  • Pseudo-transitivity rule: X → Y and YZ → U, then XZ → U

DEFINITIONS

Closure: $S^+$ = all FDs logically implied by S

Simple attribute: An attribute that cannot be further subdivided into components is a simple attribute.

Composite attribute: An attribute that can be split into components is a composite attribute.

Non-prime attribute: An attribute that is not part of any candidate key.

Prime attribute: An attribute that is a part of one of the candidate keys.

Trivial functional dependency: If X → Y and Y is the subset of X,

e.g. AB → B, B is subset of AB; A → A, A is subset of A

Non-Trivial functional dependency: If X → Y and Y is not a subset of X,

e.g. AB → C, C is not subset of AB

Partial functional dependency: the non-prime attribute is functionally dependent on part of a candidate key.

e.g. AC → B, A → D, D → B; [A]+ = {A, B, D} then B is partially dependent on AC

Transitive Functional Dependency: dependent is indirectly dependent on determinant

e.g. If A → B and B → C, then A → C is Transitive FD

Multivalued Functional Dependency: entities of the dependent set are not dependent on each other.

e.g. If A → BC and there exists no FD between B and C

Candidate Key & Super Key:

Candidate Key:

  • functionally determines all attributes of R
  • none of its subsets determines all attributes of R

Super Key:

  • set of attributes that contains a candidate key

Properties:

  • A Candidate Key is a minimum SuperKey

  • A Candidate Key is a SuperKey

  • Steps to find Key Attributes:

    R(A, B, C, D, E), FD = {A → B, BC → E, DE → A}

    1. Browse attributes on the right hand of each FD, {B, E, A} are already functionally depended.
    2. Then rest attributes {C, D} are key attributes.
    3. With Key attributes, we can check each combination to find candidate keys.
      1. [CD]+ = {C, D} → not key
      2. [ACD]+ = {A, B, C, D, E} → candidate key
      3. [BCD]+ = {B, C, D, E, A} → candidate key
      4. [CDE]+ = {C, D, E, A, B} → candidate key

  • Example:

    R(A, B, C, D, E), FD = {A → B, BC → E, DE → A}

    C, D will be key attributes since they are not depended on any attributes.

    [CD]+ = {C, D} → not key

    [ACD]+ = [BCD]+ = [CDE]+ = {A, B, C, D, E} → candidate keys are found

    Candidate keys: ACD, BCD, CDE

    Super Keys (must include CD, then find all combinations):

    ACD, BCD, CDE, ABCD, BCDE, ACDE, ABCDE

NORMAL FORMS

First Normal Form (1NF):

  • Every field must contain atomic values (i.e no sets or lists).

  • No null values.

  • Has unique key.

  • All relations are in 1NF.

  • Example:

    Not Atomic: R(Name, Course): (steve, c/c++)

    Atomic: R(Name, Course): (steve, c), (steve, c++)

Second Normal Form (2NF):

  • The table should be in the First Normal Form (1NF).
  • There should be No Partial Dependency for non-prime attributes.

Lemmas:

  • R is in 2NF if it does not contain any composite key (implies no partial dependency) and is in 1NF

  • Example:

    R(A, B, C, D), FD = {AC → B, A → D, D → B}

    We can compute the closure of [A]+ = {A, D, B}

    Therefore, A is alone capable of determining B, which means B is Partially Depends on AC.

    To decompose R and FD, we could take B out of R

    R1(A, B, C), FD = {AC → B}

    R2(A, B, D), FD = {A → D, D → B)

    Then there is no violation in both R1 and R2.

Third Normal Form (3NF):

  • The table should be in the Second Normal Form (2NF).
  • No Transitive Dependency for non-prime attributes

Lemmas (for quick identification): at least one of the following must be true

  1. X → Y is a Trivial FD
  2. X is SuperKey for R
  3. Y is part of a candidate key

  • Advantages:

    • 3NF is considered adequate for normal relational database design
    • most of the 3NF tables are free of insertion, update, and deletion anomalies.
    • 3NF always ensures functional dependency preserving and lossless

  • Example:

    R(A, B, C, D, E), FD = {A → B, A → C, C → D, A → E}

    Since A is missing on the right side of FDs, A is a key attribute.

    [A]+ = {A, B, C, D, E}, then A is candidate key.

    However, A → C & C → D implies A → D, then D is transitively dependent on A

    To decompose to R to 3NF, Take D out of R,

    R1(C, D), FD = {C → D}

    R2(A, B, C, E), FD = {A → B, A → C, A → E}

    This decomposition also in BCNF

Boyce-Codd Normal Form (BCNF) or (3.5NF):

  • The table should be in the Third Normal Form (3NF).
  • For every one of its dependencies X → Y, at least one of the following conditions hold
    1. X → Y is a trivial FD
    2. X is superkey of R

Other Lemmas:

  • Any 2-attribute relation is in BCNF.

  • BCNF decomposition may always not possible with dependency preserving, however, it always satisfies lossless join condition

  • Example:

    R(A, B, C, D, E), FD = {AB → CD, D → E, A → C, B → D}

    [AB]+ = {A, B, C, D, E}, then AB is candidate key

    D → E Violation: Transitive Dependency; D is not a Super key

    A → C Violation: Partial Dependency; A is not a Super key

    B → D Violation: Partial Dependency; B is not a Super key

    1. resolve D → E:

      R1(D, E), FD = {D → E}, (D is superkey)

      R2(A, B, C, D), FD = {AB → CD, A → C, B → D}

    2. resolve A → C and B → D: break R2

      R3(A, C), FD = {A → C}, (A is superkey)

      R4(B, D), FD = {B → D}, (B is superkey)

    Final Decomposition: R1(D, E), FD = {D → E}, R3(A, C), FD = {A → C}, R4(B, D), FD = {B → D}

    In above decomposition AB → CD is missing which is in the original relation. however we can derive AB → CD as below:

    AB → AB ⇒ AB → A and AB → B

    AB → A and A → C ⇒ AB → C

    AB → B and B → D ⇒ AB → D

    AB → C and AB → D ⇒ AB → CD

    Hence, dependency also preserved.

Other NFs:

Fourth Normal Form (4NF):

  • The table should be in the Boyce-Codd Normal Form (BCNF)
  • No Multi-valued Dependency.

Fifth Normal Form (5NF):

  • The table should be in the Fourth Normal Form (4NF).
  • Does not contain any join dependency, joining should be lossless.

Desirable Properties of Schema Decomposition

  1. MINIMIZE REDUNDANCY
  2. AVOID INFO LOSS
  3. PRESERVE DEPENDENCY
  4. ENSURE GOOD QUERY PERFORMANCE

For R (Relation) with S (FDs)→ decomposition → R1 with S1, R2 with S2

  • LOSSLESS-JOIN DECOMPOSITION

    • Lossless join decomposition is a decomposition of a relation R into relations R1, R2 such that if we perform a natural join of relation R1 and R2, it will return the original relation R.
    • S+ contains one of FDs: R1 ∩ R2 → R1 or R1 ∩ R2 → R2

  • DEPENDENCY PRESERVING

    • S+ = (S1 U S2)+
    • general form: S+ = S’+, S’ = (S1 U S2 U … U Sn)

  • Example:

    R(A, B, C) S = {A → B, B → C}

    R is not in BCNF since B is not superkey

    Decompose: R1(B, C), R2(A, B)

    • Lossless-join decomposition:

      R1 ∩ R2 = {B} and B+ = {B, C}, then B → BC

    • Dependency preserving:

      A → B is enforced in R2 B → C is enforced in R1

    Therefore, this decomposition is loss-less join and dependency preserving

BCNF and 3NF

  • BCNF removes certain types of redundancy
  • For examples of redundancy that it cannot remove, see “multi-valued redundancy”
  • BCNF avoids info loss
  • BCNF is not always dependency preserving
  • In fact, some times we cannot find a BCNF decomposition that is dependency preserving

When?

  • BCNF is not dependency preserving
  • Efficient checking for FD violation on updates is important

Define a weaker normal form, called Third Normal Form (3NF)

  • Allows some redundancy
  • But functional dependencies can be checked on individual relations without computing a join.
  • There is always a lossless-join, dependency-preserving decomposition into 3NF.

BCNF vs 3NF

It is always possible to decompose a relation into a set of relations that are in

  • 3NF
    • the decomposition is lossless
    • the dependencies are preserved
  • BCNF
    • the decomposition is lossless
    • it may not be possible to preserve dependencies.

DECOMPOSING R INTO 3NF

  1. Get a “minimal cover” of FDs

    OBTAINING MINIMAL COVER

    1. Put the FDs in a standard form (i.e. right-hand side should contain only single attribute)
    2. Minimize the left side of each FD
    3. Delete redundant FDs

    • Example

  2. Find a lossless-join decomposition of R (which might miss dependencies)

  3. Add additional relations to the decomposition to cover any missing FDs of the cover

Result will be lossless, will be dependency-preserving 3NF; might not be BCNF

NORMALIZATION SUMMARY

  • 1NF: usually part of the woodwork
  • 2NF: usually skipped
  • 3NF: a biggie­ always aim for this
  • BCNF and 4NF: tradeoffs start here ­ in re: d-preserving and losslessness
  • 5NF: You can say you’ve heard of it…

item.title: SQL
item.description:
Data Definition Language (DDL):

  • Define relational schemas
  • Create/alter/delete tables and their attributes
// Create table student
// Student(snum:int, sname:String, level:String, major:String, age:integer)
CREATE TABLE Student (
	snum BIGINT,
	sname VARCHAR(50), 
	major VARCHAR(50), 
	level CHAR(2), 
	age int,
	PRIMARY KEY (snum));

// Delete table enroll
DROP TABLE enroll;

// Add a foreign key constraint to table enroll
ALTER TABLE enroll
ADD FOREIGN KEY(snum) 
REFERENCES STUDENT(snum) 
ON UPDATE CASCADE;

ELEMENTS OF TABLE DECLARATIONS

ALTER

// add column
ALTER TABLE table_name
ADD column_name datatype;
// drop column
ALTER TABLE table_name
DROP COLUMN column_name;

  • e.g.

VIEWS

  • a “virtual table,” a relation that is defined in terms of the contents of other tables and views.
  • You may query a view as if it were a base table.
CREATE VIEW view_name AS
SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;

  • e.g.

Standard SQL requires these distinctions:

  • There can be only one PRIMARY KEY for a relation, but several UNIQUE attributes.
  • No attribute of a PRIMARY KEY can ever be NULL in any tuple. But attributes declared UNIQUE may have NULL’s, and there may be several tuples with NULL**.**

Two other declarations we can make for an attribute are:

  • NOT NULL means that the value for this attribute may never be NULL.
  • DEFAULT says that if there is no specific value known for this attribute’s component in some tuple, use the stated .

Constraints:

  • DEFAULT - Sets a default value for a column if no value is specified

    • e.g.

      CREATE TABLE CLASS (
	cname VARCHAR(255), 
	meets_at VARCHAR(255),
	room VARCHAR(255) DEFAULT 'R128’,
	fid bigint,
	PRIMARY KEY(cname));

  • NOT NULL - Ensures that a column cannot have a NULL value

  • UNIQUE - Ensures that all values in a column are different

  • PRIMARY KEY - A combination of a NOT NULL and UNIQUE. Uniquely identifies each row in a table

  • FOREIGN KEY - Prevents actions that would destroy links between tables

    • If there is a foreign-key constraint from attributes of relation R to the primary key of relation S, two violations are possible:

      1. An insert or update to R introduces values not found in S.
      2. A deletion or update to S causes some tuples of R to “dangle.”

    • Suppose R and S, to handle nonexistent S must be rejected:

      1. Default: Reject the modification.

      2. Cascade: Make the same changes in R.

        Deleted Class: delete R tuple.

        Updated Class: change value in R.

      3. Set NULL: Change S to NULL.

    • When we declare a foreign key, we may choose policies SET NULL or CASCADE independently for deletions and updates: ON [UPDATE, DELETE][SET NULL CASCADE]

    • e.g.

      // Create table ENROLL
// Enroll (snum:integer, cname:String)
CREATE TABLE ENROLL ( 
	snum BIGINT,
	cname VARCHAR(255),
	FOREIGN KEY (snum) REFERENCES student(snum),
  FOREIGN KEY (cname) REFERENCES class(cname) on UPDATE CASCADE,
	primary key(snum, cname));

// FOREIGN KEY on ALTER TABLE
ALTER TABLE Orders
ADD FOREIGN KEY (PersonID) REFERENCES Persons(PersonID);

  • CHECK - Ensures that the values in a column satisfies a specific condition

  • CREATE INDEX - Used to create and retrieve data from the database very quickly

Data Manipulation Language (DML):

  • ­Insert new tuples into relations
  • ­Delete tuples from relations
  • Modify various attributes of tuples
  • Query the database

INSRET INTO

// 1. Specify both the column names and the values to be inserted:
INSERT INTO table_name (column1, column2, column3, ...)
VALUES (value1, value2, value3, ...);
// 2. Adding values for all the columns does not need to specify the column names,
//    order of the values is in the same order as the columns: 
INSERT INTO table_name
VALUES (value1, value2, value3, ...); 
// 3. intert many values
INSERT INTO <relation> ( <subquery> );

// e.g. Insert a single tuple
INSERT INTO student(snum,sname,level,major,age) 
VALUES(51135593,'Maria White’,'SR','English',21);

DELETE

DELETE FROM table_name WHERE condition;
DELETE FROM table_name; // Delete everything

// e.g. Delete all tuples matching the a condition
DELETE FROM student WHERE Age > 10 AND Age < 15;

// e.g. Delete everything
DELETE FROM Student;

UPDATE

UPDATE table_name
SET column1 = value1, column2 = value2, ...
WHERE condition;

// e.g. Update all tuples matching a condition
UPDATE student
SET major = 'International Study'
WHERE snum = '51235593';

SELECT-FROM-WHERE

SELECT column1, column2, ... AS name1, name2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
// select all the fields available in the table
SELECT * FROM table_name;

INSIDE WHERE

  • Attribute names of the relations appearing in FROM clause

  • Comparison operators (=, <>, <, >, <=, >=)

  • Arithmetic operations (+, -, /, *)

  • AND-OR-NOT

    WHERE condition1 AND condition2 AND condition3 ...;
WHERE condition1 OR condition2 OR condition3 ...;
WHERE NOT condition;

// e.g. in where
SELECT sname
FROM Student
WHERE Age > 20 AND Age < 30;

  • LIKE - FIND PATTERNS IN STRINGS

    • The percent sign % represents zero, one, or multiple characters
    • The underscore sign _ represents one, single character
    SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
WHERE columnN LIKE pattern;

// e.g. Finds any values that start with "a" and are at least 3 characters in length
WHERE CustomerName LIKE 'a__%'

  • IN - shorthand for multiple OR conditions

    SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name IN (value1, value2, ...);
// or in SUBQUERY
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name IN (SELECT STATEMENT);

  • BETWEEN

    • The BETWEEN operator selects values within a given range. The values can be numbers, text, or dates.
    • The BETWEEN operator is inclusive: begin and end values are included.
    SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name BETWEEN value1 AND value2;

  • Operations on strings (e.g. concatenation)

  • Special functions for comparing dates and times

NULL VALUE

  • The logic of conditions in SQL is really 3-valued logic: TRUE, FALSE, UNKNOWN.
  • When any value is compared with NULL, the truth value is UNKNOWN.
  • But a query only produces a tuple in the answer if its truth value for the WHERE clause is TRUE (not FALSE or UNKNOWN).
  • To understand how AND, OR, and NOT work in 3-valued logic, think of TRUE = 1, FALSE = 0, and UNKNOWN = 1⁄2.
  • X AND Y = MIN(X, Y); X OR Y = MAX(X, Y), NOT(X) = 1-X.
  • NULL never contributes to a sum, average, or count, and can never be the minimum or maximum of a column.
  • But if there are no non-NULL values in a column, then the result of the aggregation is NULL.

IS NULL & IS NOT NULL

SELECT column_names
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name IS NULL;

ARITHMETIC EXPRESSIONS

// e.g. in select
SELECT Name, Salary * 1.1 As Bonus
FROM Employee
WHERE Age <= 30;

// e.g. in where
SELECT Name
FROM Employee
WHERE Salary / Age > 5000;

ORDER BY - SORT RESULTS

SELECT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name
ORDER BY column1, column2, ... ASC|DESC;

SELECT DISTINCT - return only distinct (different) values.

SELECT DISTINCT column1, column2, ...
FROM table_name;

MULTI-RELATION QUERIES

SELECT a1, a2, ..., ak
FROM R1 AS x1, R2 AS x2, ..., Rn AS xn 
WHERE conditions;

// e.g.
SELECT s.sname 
FROM student s, enroll e
WHERE s.snum = e.snum and e.cname LIKE 'Database Systems';

MAX() & MIN()

// The MIN() function returns the smallest value of the selected column.
SELECT MIN(column_name)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
// The MAX() function returns the largest value of the selected column.
SELECT MAX(column_name)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;

COUNT(), AVG(), & SUM()

// The COUNT() function returns the number of rows that matches a specified criterion.
SELECT COUNT(column_name)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
// count of rows
COUNT(*)
// The AVG() function returns the average value of a numeric column.
SELECT AVG(column_name)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
// The SUM() function returns the total sum of a numeric column.
SELECT SUM(column_name)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;

EXISTS

  • The EXISTS operator returns TRUE if the subquery returns one or more records.
  • NOT EXISTS () is true if and only if the is empty
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE EXISTS
(SELECT column_name FROM table_name WHERE condition);

ANY

  • boolean condition meaning that x (=, <>, !=, >, >=, <, or ≤) at least one tuple in the relation.
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name operator ANY
  (SELECT column_name
  FROM table_name
  WHERE condition);

ALL

  • returns a boolean value as a result
  • returns TRUE if ALL of the subquery values meet the condition
  • is used with SELECT, WHERE and HAVING statements
SELECT ALL column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition;
//
SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE column_name operator ALL (SUBQUERY);

UNION, INTERSECTION, EXCEPT

( subquery ) UNION ( subquery )­
( subquery ) INTERSECT ( subquery )
­( subquery ) EXCEPT ( subquery )

JOIN

R NATURAL JOIN S;
// Product
R CROSS JOIN S;
// THETA JOIN
R JOIN S ON <condition>

OUTER JOINS

  • Left outer join: ­Include the left tuple even if there’s no match
  • Right outer join: ­Include the right tuple even if there’s no match
  • Full outer join: Include the both left and right tuples even if there’s no match
R OUTER JOIN S
R NATURAL/LEFT/RIGHT/FULL OUTER JOIN S ON <condition>

DISTINCT

DISTINCT inside an aggregation causes duplicates to be eliminated before the aggregation.

// e.g.
SELECT COUNT(DISTINCT age)
FROM Student
WHERE level =‘JR’;

GROUP BY & HAVING

We may follow a SELECT-FROM-WHERE expression by GROUP BY and a list of attributes.

SELECT column_name(s)
FROM table_name
WHERE condition
GROUP BY column_name(s)
HAVING condition
ORDER BY column_name(s);

RELATIONAL ALGEBRA

  • Union: U

    • Input: R1, R2, must have the same schema
    • Output: R1 U R2 has the same schema as R1, R2
    • Union: all tuples in R1 or R2
    • Notation: R1 U R2

  • Difference: -

    • Input: R1, R2, must have the same schema
    • Output: R1 - R2 has the same schema as R1, R2
    • Difference: all tuples in R1 and not in R2
    • Notation: R1 – R2

  • ­Selection: $\sigma$

    • Input: A relation R, a condition c

    • Output: a relation $R^\prime = \sigma_c(R)$ which contains all tuples from R satisfying a condition c and R’ has the same schema as R

    • c is a condition: =, <, >, and, or, not

    • e.g.

      Find all employees with salary more than $40,000: ­$\sigma_{salary\ >\ 40000}\ (Employee)$

  • Projection: π­

    • Input: a relation R(B1, …, Bm) and a set of attributes A1, A2, …, An.

    • Output: A relation R’(A1,A2,..An) in which: ${A1, …, An}\ \subseteq\ {B1, …, Bm}$

    • Unary operation: returns certain columns A1, A2, …, An

    • Eliminates duplicate tuples !

    • Notation: $\pi_{A1,…,An}(R)$

    • e.g.

      project social-security number and names: ­$\pi_{ssn,\ name}\ (Employee)$

  • Cartesian Product: X

    • Input: $R1(A1,…,An),\ R2(B1,…,Bm), \ {{A1,…,An}} \cap {{B1,…Bm}} = \phi$

    • Output: Return the concatenation of every tuple in R1 with every tuple in R2

    • Notation: R1 x R2

    • Output schema is S(A1, …, An, B1, …, Bm)

    • e.g.

      Employee x Dependents

  • Renaming**: $\rho$**

    • Input: Input schema: R(A1, …, An)

    • Output: Output schema: S(B1, …, Bn)

      • Does not change the relational instance
      • Changes the relational schema only

    • Notation: $\rho_{B1,…,Bn}(R)$

    • e.g.

      $\rho_{LastName,\ SocSocNo}(Employee)$

  • Intersection­: $\cap$

    • Input: R1, R2 must have the same schema
    • Output:
      • $R1\ \cap\ R2$ has the same schema as R1, R2 ­
      • All tuples both in R1 and in R2
    • Notation: $R1\ \cap\ R2$
    • Intersection is derived: $R1\ \cap\ R2= R1-(R1-R2)$

JOINS (THETA-JOIN, NATURAL-JOIN, EQUI-JOIN, OTHER JOINS)

  • THETA-JOIN:

    • Notation: $R1 \bowtie_\theta R2$ where $\theta$ is the condition

    • Input schemas: R1(A1,…,An), R2(B1,…,Bm)

    • Output schema: S(A1,…,An,B1,…,Bm)

    • Derived operator: $R1 \bowtie_\theta R2 = \sigma_\theta(R1\times R2)$

    • e.g.

  • NATURAL-JOIN:

    • Notation: $R1 \bowtie R2$

    • Input Schema: R1(A1, …, An), R2(B1, …, Bm)

    • Output Schema: *S(C1,…,Cp)*­ Where {C1, …, Cp} = {A1, …, An} U {B1, …, Bm}

    • Meaning: combine all pairs of tuples in R1 and R2 that agree on the attributes: ${{A1,…,An}} \cap {{B1,…Bm}}$ (called the join attributes)

    • e.g.

      ****Given the relations R(A, B, C, D) and S(B, D, E):

      $r \bowtie s = π_{r.A,r.B,r.C,r.D,s.E}(σ_{r.B=s.B∧r.D=s.D}(r × s))$

  • EQUI-JOIN:

    • Return all the combinations of tuples of R1 and R2 which satisfy the equality condition A=B

      • ­Equi-join is a special case of theta join
      • Natural join is a special case of equi-join

    • Most frequently used in practice: $R1 \bowtie_{A=B} R2$

    • e.g

  • more examples

  • OUTER-JOIN:

item.title: PROCEDURES and FUNCTIONS
item.description:
e.g.

delimiter $$
drop procedure if exists getStudent;
create procedure getStudent(IN studentName VARCHAR(255)) 
begin
select *
from STUDENT
where sname = studentName;
end $$ 
delimiter ;

delimiter $$
Drop procedure if exists updateStudentTable; 
create procedure updateStudentTable() 
begin
update student set age =22 where sname ='Edward Baker';
update student set major = 'Architecture' where sname = 'Charles Harris'; 
end $$
delimiter ;

DATABASE API

ODBC (Open Database Connectivity) works with C, C++, C#, and Visual Basic

JDBC (Java Database Connectivity) works with Java

JDBC STEPS

  1. Importing Packages
  2. Registering the JDBC Drivers
  3. Opening a Connection to a Database
  4. Creating a Statement Object
  5. Executing a Query and Returning a Result Set Object
  6. Processing the Result Set
  7. Closing the Result Set and Statement Objects
  8. Closing the Connection

item.title: mySQL
item.description:
# First go to the user home directory.
$ cd ~
$ pwd
/Users/yuxizheng

# Edit the user .bash_pforile file.
$ sudo vim .bash_profile

# Add below content at the end of the .bash_profile file. Save and exit.
# Add MySQL binary folder in the macOS system environment variable PATH.
PATH="/usr/local/mysql/bin:${PATH}"
export PATH

# Verify the .bash_profile has been changed as required.
$ cat .bash_profile

# Make the above changes take effect in macOS.
$ source .bash_profile

# Now you can run mysql command directly in terminal to connect to the MySQL database server.
$ mysql -u root -p

# login
# /usr/local/mysql/bin/mysql -u root -p
mysql -u root -p
mysql --local-infile=1 -u root -p

A1b2C3d4&

# set password
SET PASSWORD = PASSWORD('[newpassword]');
SET PASSWORD = PASSWORD('[1234567890]');

SET GLOBAL local_infile = true;

# show databases
show databases;

# select database
use <db>

# list tables
show tables;

# show table
describe <table>;

# load data
load data local infile 'path to the csv file' into table <table> fields terminated by ',' lines terminated by '\n';

# exit mysql
exit

ERROR 2068 (HY000): LOAD DATA LOCAL INFILE file request rejected due to restrictions on access


load data local infile '/Users/yuxizheng/xizheng/2022-SUMMER/cs564/lab1/universitydb/Enroll.csv' into table Enroll fields terminated by ',' lines terminated by '\r\n';

// 13
select s.sname 
from student s
where s.snum in (
select e1.snum
from enroll e1, enroll e2, class c1, class c2 
where c1.cname != c2.cname AND c1.meets_at = c2.meets_at AND e1.snum = e2.snum AND
e1.cname = c1.cname AND e2.cname = c2.cname);

// 20
select s1.age, s1.level
from student s1
group by s1.age, s1.level
having s1.level in (
select s2.level
from student s2
where s1.age = s2.age
group by s2.age, s2.level
having count(*) >= ALL(
select count(*) from student s3 where s2.age = s3.age group by s3.age, s3.level));

// 17
select f.fname, count(c.cname) AS num
from class c, faculty f 
where c.fid = f.fid
group by f.fname
having f.fname NOT IN (select f1.fname
from class c1, faculty f1 
where c1.fid = f1.fid and c1.cname NOT IN
(select c2.cname from class c2 where c2.room = 'R128'));

CREATE TABLE assets (
	symbol VARCHAR(50), 
	date DATE,
	open DOUBLE,
	high DOUBLE,
	low DOUBLE,
	close DOUBLE,
	volume DOUBLE,
	PRIMARY KEY (symbol, date));

	price VARCHAR(50), 
	PRIMARY KEY (symbol, date));

CREATE TABLE country (
	symbol VARCHAR(50), 
	name VARCHAR(50), 
	continent VARCHAR(50), 
	PRIMARY KEY (symbol));

SELECT a.symbol, AVG(a.close)
FROM assets a, commo c
Where c.symbol = a.symbol AND a.symbol IN (
SELECT DISTINCT symbol 
FROM assets 
WHERE date BETWEEN '2005-01-01' AND '2005-12-31')
GROUP BY a.symbol
ORDER BY AVG(a.close) ASC
LIMIT 5;

SELECT c.symbol, COUNT(a.date)
FROM assets a, commo c 
Where c.symbol = a.symbol 
GROUP BY c.symbol
ORDER BY COUNT(a.date) DESC
LIMIT 10;

mysqldump -u root -p 564project > ./sql-data-backup.sql

item.title: DISK
item.description:
DISK

A disk with Sector size 512 bytes ­2000 tracks per surface ­50 sectors per track ­5 double-sided platters ­Average seek time: 10msec 5400 revolutions per minute (rpm)

  • Capacity of track:
  • Sector size * Sectors 512 * 50 = 25600 bytes = 25 KB
  • Capacity of surface:
  • Capacity of track * surfaces 25KB * 2000 = 50,000 KB
  • Capacity of disk:
  • Capacity of surface * platters 50,000 KB * 5 * 2 = 500,000 KB
  • Cylinders:
  • Cylinders = Track on each platter 2000
  • Valid block size:
  • Integer multiplication of sector size 256: No, 256 = 0.5 * 512 2048: Yes, 2048 = 512 * 4
  • Maximum rotational delay:
  • Maximum rotational delay = time required for one complete rotation = 60 * 1 / rpm 60 * 1/5400 = 0.011 seconds
  • Transfer rate
  • transfer rate = track size / time required for one revolution 25KB / 0.011 seconds = 2272 KB/sec

BUFFER MANAGEMENT

  • Pin count: number of users of the page
  • Pin a page: indicate that the page is in use (pin count > 0)­
  • Unpin a page: release the page, and also indicate whether the page is dirtied (pin count = 0)
  • Dirty bit: indicates whether the page has been modified and the changes need to be propagated to the disk

LEAST RECENTLY USED (LRU)

MOST RECENTLY USED (MRU)

RECORD ORGANIZATION

File organization

  • Heap file­
    • As doubly-linked list
    • Using page directory

Page organization­

  • For fixed-length records
    • Packed­
    • Unpacked
  • For variable-length records

B+ TREE

Advantages:

  • automatically reorganizes itself with small, local, changes, in the face of insertions and deletions.
  • reorganization of entire file is not required to maintain performance

Disadvantages:

  • extra insertion and deletion overhead, space overhead.

General Properties:

  • All paths from root to leaf are of the same length
  • Two types of nodes: index (internal) nodes and data (leaf) nodes.
  • Each node is one disk page.
  • Parameter d = the order (or the degree)
  • Each node must have minimum 50% occupancy (except root)
  • Each node and leaf has d ≤ m ≤ 2d keys

VIEDO

B+ Tree Basics 1

B+ Trees Basics 2 (insertion)

B+ Tree Basics 3

item.title: Hash Sorting
item.description:
Static Hashing

  • A hash index is a collection of buckets
  • N = number of buckets
  • h(k) mod N = bucket in which the data entry belongs
  • Equality search
    • Apply the hash function on the search key value to locate the appropriate bucket
    • Search through the primary page (and possibly overflow pages if they exist) to find the matching record(s)
  • Deletion
    • Find the appropriate bucket, delete the record
    • Possibly delete the overflow page
  • Insertion
    • Find the appropriate bucket, insert the record
    • If there is no space, create a new overflow page

Dynamic Hashing

  • Good for database that grows and shrinks in size
  • Allows the hash function to be modified dynamically
  • If local depth = Global depth
    • We need to double the size of table, add new bucket, redistribute data, update pointers
  • If local depth < global depth
    • Add new bucket, redistribute data, update pointers
  • Benefits of extendable hashing:
    • Hash performance does not degrade with growth of file
    • Minimal space overhead
  • Disadvantages of extendable hashing: Extra level of indirection to find desired record
    • Bucket address table may itself become very big (larger than memory) Cannot allocate very large contiguous areas on disk either
    • Solution: B+ tree structure to locate desired record in bucket address table
    • Changing size of bucket address table is an expensive operation

Sort

  • Internal Sorting (data is in memory at all time while the sorting is in progress)
    • Heapsort, Quicksort
  • External Sorting (data is stored on disk and only small chunks are loaded inside the memory)
    • 2-way merge sort, Multiway Mergesort
  • Choice of internal sort algorithm may matter
    • Quicksort: Quick!­
    • Replacement sort: slower, longer runs
  • Clustered B+ tree is good for sorting
    • Unclustered tree is usually very bad
  • Clustered B+ tree: The search key order corresponds to the order in which the data records are stored.

2-WAY EXTERNAL MERGE SORT

  • B = 2
  • N = number of pages
  • Number of passes = $\lceil \log_2N \rceil + 1$
  • Total Cost = $2N(\lceil \log_2N \rceil + 1)$

GENERAL (MULTI-WAY) EXTERNAL MERGE-SORT

  • B: number of available buffer pages
  • N: number of pages in R
  • Number of passes = $\lceil \log_{B-1} \lceil {N \over B} \rceil \rceil + 1$
    • 1 pass to create initial sorted runs
    • $\lceil \log_{B-1} \lceil {N \over B} \rceil \rceil$ to merge runs repeatedly
  • Number of I/Os per pass = 2N
  • Hence, total cost = $2N (\lceil \log_{B-1} \lceil {N \over B} \rceil \rceil + 1)$

item.title: Selection, Projection, Join Algos
item.description:
Selection

Projection

Join

nested loop

Cost: T(R) * T(S) (e.g: 100,000 x 40,000 = 4 x 10e9 I/O

Assuming that each I/O takes 10ms -> this will take about 11,111 hours

index nested loop

block-based nested loop join

Cost = Outer table pages + ( Outer table pages / blocksize ) * inner table pages

block index nested loop

sort-merge join

Total cost: EMS(R)+ EMS(S) + merging_cost (∈[T(R)+T(S), T(R) *T(S)]) Merging cost: T(R)+T(S) is guaranteed in foreign key join;

hash join

GENERAL JOIN CONDITIONS

Multiple equalities­

  • e.g. R.a = S.b ∧ R.c = S.d
  • Hash Join works fine: hash R on (a, c) and S on (b, d)­
  • Sort Merge Join works fine: sort S on (a, c) and S on (b, d)
  • ­Index Nested Loop Join: use (build, if needed) a matching index on S

Inequalities

  • ­e.g. R.a > S.b
  • ­Hash Join and Sort Merge Join not applicable­
  • Index Nested Loop Join: use (build, if needed) a B+tree index on S
  • Block Nested Loop Join might often be among the best choices
  • ­Inequality checks might lead to large outputs

item.title: QUERY PERFORMANCE
item.description:
DB STATISTICS

  • Number of tuples (cardinality) T(R)
  • Indexes, number of keys in the index V(R,a)
  • Number of physical pages B(R)
  • Min value, Max value, V(R,a)

CARDINALITY AND COST ESTIMATION

  • file scan - B(R)
  • selection - B(R) * selectivity
  • nested loop - B(R) + T(R)* B(S)
  • Index nested loop
    • If index on S is clustered (default): B(R) + T(R)B(S)/V(S,a)
    • If index on S is unclustered: B(R) + T(R)T(S)/V(S,a)
  • block based nested loop - B(S) + B(R)*B(S)/M
  • sort merge - 3B(R)+3B(S)
  • hash join - 3B(R) + 3B(S)

SELECTIVITY FACTOR

  • RULE OF THUMB - If selectivities are unknown, then selectivity factor = 1/10

  • Condition is A = c (value selection on R)

    Selectivity = 1 / V(R,A)

  • Condition is A < c (range selection on R)

    Selectivity = (c - Low(R, A))/(High(R,A) - Low(R,A))

  • Condition is A = B ($R \bowtie_{A=B} S$)

    Selectivity = 1 / max(V(R,A),V(S,A))

  • In general:

    $T(R \bowtie_{A=B} S) = T(R)T(S) / \max(V(R,A), V(S,B))$

EQUIVALENCE RULES

1. Conjunctive selection operations can be deconstructed into a sequence of individual selections.

$\sigma_{\theta_1 \wedge \theta_2}(E) = \sigma_{\theta_1}(\sigma_{\theta_2}(E))$

2. Selection operations are commutative.

$\sigma_{\theta_1}(\sigma_{\theta_2}(E)) = \sigma_{\theta_2}(\sigma_{\theta_1}(E))$

3. Only the last in a sequence of projection operations is needed, the others can be omitted.

4. Selections can be combined with Cartesian products and theta joins.

$\sigma_{\theta}(E_1 \times E_2) = E1 \Join_{\theta} E_2$

$\sigma_{\theta_1}(E_1 \Join_{\theta_2} E_2) = E1 \Join_{\theta1 \wedge \theta2} E_2$

5. Theta-join operations (and natural joins) are commutative.

$E_1 \Join_\theta E_2 = E_2 \Join_\theta E_1$

6. (a) Natural join operations are associative:

$(E_1 \Join E_2) \Join E_3 = E_1 \Join (E_2 \Join E_3)$

**(b) Theta joins are associative in the following manner:**

$(E_1 \Join_{\theta_1} E_2) \Join_{\theta2 \wedge \theta3} E_3 = E_1 \Join_{\theta1 \wedge \theta3} (E_2 \Join_{\theta_2} E_3)$

7. The selection operation distributes over the theta join operation under the following two conditions:

(a) When all the attributes in θ0 involve only the attributes of one of the expressions (E1) being joined.

(b) When θ1 involves only the attributes of E1 and θ2 involves only the attributes of E2.
